Healthy.name: Healthy Leaf
Healthy.summary: Leaf appears largely healthy. Maintain good agronomic practices.
symptoms: No significant spots or powdery patches
management: Maintain balanced fertilization based on soil test
Water at the base, avoid prolonged leaf wetness
Scout weekly to catch early signs of issues
organic: Compost and mulch to improve soil health

Leaf Spot.name: Leaf Spot Complex
Leaf Spot.summary: Circular to irregular brown/black lesions, sometimes with yellow halo. Common in many crops.
symptoms: Small dark spots that may enlarge or coalesce
Severe cases cause premature leaf drop
management: Remove and destroy heavily infected leaves
Avoid overhead irrigation; ensure good airflow
organic: Apply neem oil (0.5–1%) at 7–10 day intervals
Use baking soda + horticultural oil sprays as protectants
chemicals: Copper oxychloride or copper hydroxide as protectant
Chlorothalonil, mancozeb as per label rates

Powdery Mildew.name: Powdery Mildew
Powdery Mildew.summary: White, powdery fungal growth on leaf surfaces, thrives in humid but not necessarily wet conditions.
symptoms: White powder-like patches on upper leaf surface
Distorted or stunted growth in severe cases
management: Remove infected leaves to reduce inoculum
Improve air circulation; avoid dense canopy
chemicals: Myclobutanil, tebuconazole, trifloxystrobin as per label

Nutrient Deficiency.name: Likely Nutrient Imbalance
Nutrient Deficiency.summary: General yellowing or interveinal chlorosis may indicate N, Mg, or Fe deficiency.
symptoms: Older leaves yellow first (often N/Mg), younger leaves (often Fe)
management: Conduct soil test to confirm deficiencies
Apply balanced fertilizer; ensure proper pH
Avoid overwatering which can induce nutrient lockout
